d:objective.d:objective: Provide an environment for programs that acts as an generic interface and abstracts away implementation details of the environment. Environment is implemented via interfaces and object, but only accessed via interfaces. Implement side effects like input and output only over this environment. Implement path, file and network connection system.

Minimize complexity. Maximize compatibility to other programming paradigms and make it therefore easy to translate automatically or manually to other languages. Work with only one state variable. Support different types of environment object variable. Support environment object access via a variable that is passed through everywhere.
Support environment object access via a static variable. Support environment object access via thread local variable.
Use no inheritance. Use dependency injection via static methods.
Minimize side effects. Split everything into core, merger, sheath, environment. No explicit splitting in order to safe development resources. It is enough to ensure, that it is possible to split everything at any given time, with an acceptable amount of resources.

s:chapter.s:title: Side Effects
s:chapter.s:paragraph: Secondary side effects are parts of the programs which are undefined. Primary side effects are modeled side effects that are explicitly caused by the program.
Configuration of secondary effects are done with secondary effects or the executor of the programs. Configuration of primary effects are done via program arguments or the executor.

s:chapter.s:title: Program Dependencies
s:chapter.s:paragraph: There are runtime dependencies and compile time dependencies. Runtime dependencies are arguments and configurations for primary and secondary side effects.
